attributes.title: Combinatorial and emergent effects of institutional pressures

q1.value: Combinatorial and Emergent Effects of Institutional Pressures

q2.value: Kazem Haki, Marcel Cahenzli, Patrick Haack, Stephan Aier

q3.value: Institutional Theory has been around for a long time in management and organizational literature. The micro-institutional view on organizations thereby posits that individual behaviour is influenced and shaped by coercive (authority), normative (social) and mimetic (cognitive-cultural) pressures. These pressures push individuals toward behaviour that complies with these pressures because this provides people with legitimacy in their actions. What remains unclear however, is whether and how these pressures interact and create potential emergent effects.

q4.value:
H1.1: The impact of coercive pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by normative pressure.
H1.2: The impact of coercive pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by mimetic pressure.
H1.3: The impact of coercive pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by the combination of normative and mimetic pressure.
H2.1: The impact of normative pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by coercive pressure.
H2.2: The impact of normative pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by mimetic pressure.
H2.3: The impact of normative pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by the combination of coercive and mimetic pressure.
H3.1: The impact of mimetic pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by coercive pressure.
H3.2: The impact of mimetic pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by normative pressure.
H3.3: The impact of mimetic pressure on individuals' decisions is moderated by the combination of coercive and normative pressure.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Behavioural experiment in a full factorial between subjects desgin with 2 levels (added vs not added pressure) of 3 pressures (coercive, normative, mimetic). Subjects are randomly assigned and there will be repeated measures (i.e. after 1 day, 3 days, and 5 days). Participants will only be informed about their participation in the experiment after the last measure has been taken.

q9.value: We will use Random Sequence Generator to generate a sequence of numbers which map to a list of participants. In the order within the generated sequence, participants will be assigned to the conditions (first one to condition 1, second one to condition 2, ...) The random number list used to create these four blocks will be created using the web applications available at http://random.org.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited unbeknownst of their particpation. The participants are university students in their natural environment (natural field experiment). There will be no remuneration (neither monetary nor non-monetary) and all students from a specific masters studies course will partake in the study (181 students as of 25th of February 2020, drop-outs until experiment possible).

q13.value: Our target sample size is 180 participants. We will recruit them without them knowing about the experiment.

q14.value: Having conducted a vignette study on the exact same hypotheses and topic, we try to replicate the results in a natural field experiment. For this, we use a university class, whithin which the number of participants is 180 (as of 25th of February 2020, drop-outs until experiment possible). All participants will inevitable be part of the experiment.

question.value:
The independent variables are: coercive pressure, normative pressure, mimetic pressure
The levels are "with added pressure" and "without added pressure."
The manipulations are text-based elicitations of the above pressures, and they are administered via information email by the professor of the masters course (not part of the author team).

The dependent variable is the behaviour which follows upon the reception of the email. The behaviour is measured after 1 day, 3 days and 5 days as follows:
-	Did the student start the quiz? (binary)
-	Did the student finish the quiz? (binary)
-	Did the student achieve a high score/rate of correct answers? (percent)
-	Did the student start several attempts? (number of attempts)

We use Chi-Square test to investigate whether the various groups behave the same (i.e. whether their behavioural response as measured by the dependent variable measures is equal (H0)). We will not aggregate the dependent variables and thus run several Chi-Square tests, one for each measure.

q21.value: We use alpha = 0.05 for the ChiSquare probability.

q22.value: The only data that we exclude is from students that drop the course (i.e. who drop out of the course with or without notifying the professor).

q23.value: The data accounts for 'no reaction' and since the measurements are generated based on system logs, there will be no missing or incomplete data.

q1.value: Effect of sex and compensation on implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts.

q3.value: Studies have shown that gender affects attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, and the meta-analysis results show that the main effects of both gender and compensation are significant when the compensation variable is added. Therefore, we will consider the two variables of gender and compensation at the same time to explore whether the two variables have an impact on attitudes about mathematics vs. arts.

q4.value:
1. Women will show more negative attitudes with mathematics than men;
2. The volunteers will show more negative attitudes with mathematics than others.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design with 2 factor. The two between-subject factors are sex (female, male) and compensation (course credit, paid, or volunteer).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited  at many different universities. Participants will be paid $10 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value:
Our target sample size is 4811 participants.
Three priori tests were conducted as follows, in which the maximum sample size is taken as the appropriate number of samples for the study. First, the Sex variable has 2 levels, numerator df is 1. The eta square calculated in JASP is 0.018, and get the f value after conversion. The estimated sample size calculated in G*power is 431; Second, the compensation variable has 3 levels, and numerator df is 2. The eta square calculated in JASP is 0.002, and get the f value after conversion. The estimated sample size calculated in G*power is 4811; Third, the interaction term was not significant, and the eta square calculated in JASP below 0.001. Therefore, this interaction term is not considered. In summary, the study should set the sample size to 4811.

question.value: The critical dependent variable was a difference in response latency that we computed by measuring the average speed to respond to math and pleasant items when they were paired together (while unpleasant items were paired with a contrasting category, e.g., language) and the average speed to respond to math and unpleasant items when they were paired together (while pleasant items were paired with a contrasting category). The difference in average response latency was taken as an implicit assessment of preference (e.g., liking for math relative to the arts).
We will use a  2 X 3 factorial ANOVA with both factors between subjects to analyze our results.

attributes.title: LISS Panel: Financial scarcity, avoidance motivation, and social exclusion

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: LISS Panel: Financial scarcity, avoidance motivation, and social exclusion

other.value: The data of the first wave have already been collected while the data of wave 2 and 3 have not. We now preregister the longitudinal analyses and hypotheses that combine the data of wave 1, 2, and 3.

sample.value: The first wave consisted of 1114 participants. In the remaining two waves, all these participants are invited to participate again. We expect the drop-out rate to be considerable.

analyses.value:
H1:
We will fit a cross-lagged panel model (CLPM), spanning three time points to our data with Financial scarcity and Avoidance motivation as variables. We test if higher Financial scarcity at time t predicts increased Avoidance motivation at time t+1 (H1a), and/or whether higher Avoidance motivation at time t predicts increased Financial scarcity at time t+1 (H1b).

H2:
We will fit a cross-lagged panel model (CLPM), spanning three time points to our data with Financial scarcity and Exclusion as variables. We test if higher Financial scarcity at time t predicts higher Feelings of exclusion at time t+1 (H2a). We also explore if higher Feelings of exclusion at time t predict higher Financial scarcity at time t+1 (H2b).

H3: 
We will fit a cross-lagged panel model (CLPM), spanning three time points to our data with Financial scarcity and Need fulfilment as variables. We test if higher Financial scarcity at time t predicts decreased Need fulfilment at time t+1 (H3a). We also explore if decreased Need fulfilment at time t predicts higher Financial scarcity at time t+1 (H3b).

For all CLPM results we will report the results of the model with fixed intercepts, unless a chi-square test indicates that the model with random intercepts (RI-CLPM) has a better fit.

H4:
We will conduct within-subjects mediation analyses of the data of 3 different time points, to test if there is a significant indirect effect of scarcity on exclusion through stigmatization, participation, and social network, when all are entered simultaneously into a model with 10000 bootstrap resamples.

outliers.value: Participants who did not finish the complete surveys at all three time points are excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
All items are measured on a seven-point Likert-scale ranging from 1 = totally disagree to 7 = totally agree. Before items are merged to a single scale, they will be checked for reliability.

Psychological Inventory of Financial Scarcity (PIFS):
The PIFS consists of 4 subscales with 3 items each, measuring participants’ subjective experience of lacking money (e.g., “I often don’t have enough money”), worry and rumination about their finances (e.g., “I worry about money a lot”), short-term focus (e.g., “Because of my financial situation, I live from day to day”) and perceived control over their finances (e.g., “When I think about my financial situation, I feel powerless”). 

Avoidance motivation:
The scale consists of 2 subscales with 4 items each, measuring participants information avoidance (e.g. "Sometimes it feels unpleasant to think about my financial situation") and participants decision avoidance (e.g. "I sometimes delay making financial decisions until it is too late"). 

Social exclusion: 
To measure exclusion participants respond to 2 items. “Because of my financial situation…” “…I feel excluded by society”, and “…I feel rejected by society”. 

Need fulfillment:
To measure needs, participants respond to 8 items: “Because of my financial situation…” “I feel accepted by society” and “I feel like I belong” (belonging), “I feel like others decide a lot of things for me”, and “I feel like I am in control of what I do or don’t do” (control), “I feel good about myself” and “my self-esteem is high” (self-esteem), and “I feel invisible in society” and “I feel that my existence is meaningful” (meaningful existence). 

Stigma:
Stigma is measured with 2 items. “Others have negative stereotypes about people in my financial situation” and “My financial situation has a negative effect on how others act towards me”.

Participation in society:
Participation is assessed with 2 items: “Because of my financial situation I take part in recreational or social activities less often than do others (for example, sports, active member of an association)” and “Because of my financial situation I sometimes cannot participate in social activities, when I do want to”.

Social network:
Social network, finally, is also assessed with 2 items. “I feel like I have a tight social network” and “I feel part of a social group that I can always rely on”.

conditions.value: There will be no experimental conditions. We will measure the above questions three times following a repeated-measures design.

hypothesis.value:
H1a. Higher financial scarcity leads to more avoidance motivation over time.
H1b. Higher avoidance motivation leads to higher financial scarcity over time.

H2a. Higher financial scarcity leads to increased feelings of exclusion over time.
H2b. Higher feelings of exclusion lead to higher financial scarcity over time.

H3a. Higher financial scarcity leads to lower need fulfillment over time.
H3b. Lower need fulfillment leads to higher financial scarcity over time.

H4. The positive relation between financial scarcity and feelings of exclusion is mediated by feelings of stigmatization, participation in society, and social network factors.

attributes.title: Do adults with unilateral neurological conditions have altered interhemispheric inhibition compared to healthy controls?

q1.value: Do adults with unilateral neurological conditions have altered interhemispheric inhibition compared to healthy controls?

q2.value: Ashraf Gerges, Carolyn Berryman, Brenton Hordacre, G. Lorimer Moseley

q3.value: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is a disabling disorder. It results in excreting pain that is disproportionate to the inciting event (Kemler & Furnée 2002). Pain is often accompanied with sensory and motor disturbances (Borchers 2013). This perhaps reflects the complexity of the underlying pathophysiology of CRPS (Marinus et al. 2011). Current research suggests that CRPS is associated with cortical changes such as the differences between the hand representations in the somatosensory cortex S1 between the affected and unaffected side ( Di Pietro et al. 2013; Shokouhi et al. 2018; Swart et al. 2009). Comparison can be drawn between CRPS and other neurological conditions that mainly presents unilaterally such as stroke (Borich et al. 2015; Van Hilten 2010). For example, some people with CRPS show motor dysfunctions like those present in stroke. Furthermore, in stroke there is evidence for imbalance between the sensorimotor cortices of the affected and unaffected sides and treatments modulating these imbalances have been found to be effective (Borich et al. 2015).  Indeed, investigating the cortical changes in unilateral neurological conditions including CRPS will help to improve our understanding of the pathophysiology this disorder to guide future research and to generate clearer treatment targets.

q4.value: People with unilateral neurological condition have altered interhemispheric inhibition between the sensorimotor areas of the two brain hemispheres compared to healthy controls.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of observational studies. Studies that use any neurophysiological technique that measures functional brain activities to quantify interhemispheric inhibition in people with unilateral neurological condition will be included. A meta-analysis will be conducted whenever possible. The primary researcher ran the search strategy once in each database. Search results were imported into Endnote. Search results were uploaded into Convidence and duplicates were removed automatically. Two researchers will screen the search findings for eligibility independently, using article titles and abstracts for inclusion of appropriate articles bases on the specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. When it is unclear weather the study met all of the inclusion criteria on the initial title/abstract screening, the full text will be screened to assess eligibility. When there is disagreement between the two researchers on the eligibility of a particular article, a third researcher will assess this article eligibility and make a decision. No files selected. Two authors will independently extract data from the included articles using a standardised data extraction form that is designed specifically for this review. Extracted data will include the following information: demographics of study participants, the medical condition and duration of the condition, functional neurophysiological technique used, sample size and measure of interhemispheric / transcallosal inhibition.  The included studies will be appraised by independently two researchers using the Joanna Briggs Institute Critical Appraisal tools: Checklist for Case Control Studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This is systematic review and a search strategy has been developed but we are unaware of synthesis of the studies because data extraction and full text screening has not commenced yet.

question.value: The following databases have been searched from inception until October 2019: MEDLINE, Cochrane Library, EMBASE, EMCARE, ad Scopus with no restrictions. An experienced librarian aided with designing the search strategy and the attached Medline strategy was set and it was adapted as required for other databases.  Inclusion criteria: adults aged 18 years or older, with a confirmed diagnosis of a unilateral neurological diagnosis such as stroke, complex regional pain syndrome, traumatic brain injury, cerebral palsy, or motor neuron disease. Only studies that were done on humans, included a healthy control group, and used a neurophysiological technique to measure interhemispheric inhibition. Case studies, non-peer reviewed articles, conference abstracts and studies that only used a structural measure of brain interhemispheric connectivity will be excluded.

q13.value: This is a systematic review and no sample size is required.

question.value: There is  no interventions

Demographics of the subjects
Neurophysiological measures of interhemispheric /transcallosal inhibition (IHI/TCI)
The condition and its duration
NA

In order to evaluate the differences between the interhemispheric inhibition of people with unilateral neurological conditions and healthy controls. All measures of interhemispheric inhibitions, measured at rest will be extracted (mean and standard deviation), or whenever needed the standard deviation will be calculated using the formula SD= 0.75 x interquartile range, and assuming the median approximate the mean. Data will be analysed using a random effect model to combine results of individual studies and report the mean differences or the standardised mean differences. Data will be reported with 95% confidence intervals (Cis). 
The random-effects model will be used in consideration of the expected heterogeneity between studies due to the differences in the functional neurophysiological testing models. We will assess heterogeneity between studies using I2 statistic, if heterogeneity is greater than 50% it will be considered substantial.

q21.value: P- value of less than 0.05 of difference between healthy controls and people with unilateral neurological conditions will be used in meta-analysis.

q22.value: This is a systematic review of observational data that has been extracted at one point in time and no data will be excluded.

q23.value: Will contact authors up to two  times via email to collect missing data. If we received no reply we will proceed with the data analysis without these data.

q24.value: We will be exploring the interaction between the duration of condition and the interhemispheric inhibition .

registration_responses.q13: This is a systematic review and no sample size is required.
registration_responses.q21: P- value of less than 0.05 of difference between healthy controls and people with unilateral neurological conditions will be used in meta-analysis.
registration_responses.q22: This is a systematic review of observational data that has been extracted at one point in time and no data will be excluded.
registration_responses.q23: Will contact authors up to two  times via email to collect missing data. If we received no reply we will proceed with the data analysis without these data.
registration_responses.q24: We will be exploring the interaction between the duration of condition and the interhemispheric inhibition .
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a systematic review of observational studies. Studies that use any neurophysiological technique that measures functional brain activities to quantify interhemispheric inhibition in people with unilateral neurological condition will be included. A meta-analysis will be conducted whenever possible. The primary researcher ran the search strategy once in each database. Search results were imported into Endnote. Search results were uploaded into Convidence and duplicates were removed automatically. Two researchers will screen the search findings for eligibility independently, using article titles and abstracts for inclusion of appropriate articles bases on the specified inclusion and exclusion criteria. When it is unclear weather the study met all of the inclusion criteria on the initial title/abstract screening, the full text will be screened to assess eligibility. When there is disagreement between the two researchers on the eligibility of a particular article, a third researcher will assess this article eligibility and make a decision. No files selected. Two authors will independently extract data from the included articles using a standardised data extraction form that is designed specifically for this review. Extracted data will include the following information: demographics of study participants, the medical condition and duration of the condition, functional neurophysiological technique used, sample size and measure of interhemispheric / transcallosal inhibition.  The included studies will be appraised by independently two researchers using the Joanna Briggs Institute Critical Appraisal tools: Checklist for Case Control Studies.
registration_responses.q12.question: The following databases have been searched from inception until October 2019: MEDLINE, Cochrane Library, EMBASE, EMCARE, ad Scopus with no restrictions. An experienced librarian aided with designing the search strategy and the attached Medline strategy was set and it was adapted as required for other databases.  Inclusion criteria: adults aged 18 years or older, with a confirmed diagnosis of a unilateral neurological diagnosis such as stroke, complex regional pain syndrome, traumatic brain injury, cerebral palsy, or motor neuron disease. Only studies that were done on humans, included a healthy control group, and used a neurophysiological technique to measure interhemispheric inhibition. Case studies, non-peer reviewed articles, conference abstracts and studies that only used a structural measure of brain interhemispheric connectivity will be excluded.

Demographics of the subjects
Neurophysiological measures of interhemispheric /transcallosal inhibition (IHI/TCI)
The condition and its duration
registration_responses.q18.question: NA
registration_responses.q19.question:
In order to evaluate the differences between the interhemispheric inhibition of people with unilateral neurological conditions and healthy controls. All measures of interhemispheric inhibitions, measured at rest will be extracted (mean and standard deviation), or whenever needed the standard deviation will be calculated using the formula SD= 0.75 x interquartile range, and assuming the median approximate the mean. Data will be analysed using a random effect model to combine results of individual studies and report the mean differences or the standardised mean differences. Data will be reported with 95% confidence intervals (Cis). 
The random-effects model will be used in consideration of the expected heterogeneity between studies due to the differences in the functional neurophysiological testing models. We will assess heterogeneity between studies using I2 statistic, if heterogeneity is greater than 50% it will be considered substantial.

attributes.title: A cohort study investigating the association of the maternal gut microbiome and the growth of children in Indonesia

q1.value: A cohort study investigating the association of the maternal gut microbiome and the growth of children in Indonesia

q2.value: Andi Imam Arundhana Thahir, Prof Adrienne Gordon, A/Prof Andrew J Holmes, Prof Mu Li, Prof Veni Hadju, A/Prof Ansariadi

q3.value: A few studies reported the involvement of the gut microbiome in pregnancy and in children. However, it is unclear whether maternal gut microbiome can affect the assembly of the infant gut microbiome. Also, the effect of this association on infant growth has not been explored. Therefore, this study aims to investigate this process through a cohort study following pregnant women at 3rd trimester up to six month of the age of their infants. In a particular population, pregnant women will receive different types of supplementation. Thus, this study also evaluate whether this intervention affects the gut microbiome composition.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that:
1. The maternal gut microbiome may determine the infant gut microbiome colonization but can be modified by mode of delivery and maternal nutrition.
2. The infant gut microbiome is associated with the growth
3. There is no effect of the supplementation intervention on the maternal gut microbiome.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a cohort study recruiting pregnant women from the late pregnancy (>28 weeks of gestation) and follow up until the age of their children reached 6 months. The population observed in this study will receive supplements as a part of the government program for pregnant women to reduce the incidence of stunting.

They will be received a capsule of the supplement per day, either multimicronutrient (MM) or iron-folic acid (IFA). Within the MM group, there are sub-groups, MM preconception and MM non-preconception.
MM preconception means that pregnant women receive MM supplement before their pregnancy or immediately after they got married. Meanwhile, non-preconception means that they get MM supplement after they are identified pregnant. For IFA group, they are only non-preconception due to this program is planning to be diminished and will be changed to only MM supplement in this area.

Each MM supplement contains 30mg iron and 400mg folic acid and other 13 micronutrients, while IFA contains 60mg iron and 400mg folic acid.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: The stage of data collection has not been started. However, to start the data collection, we obtained the data of pregnant women in the research site from the District Health Office of Banggai Regency.

question.value:
Participants (age 18-49 years, gestational age 28 weeks and above, and planning to stay in the research site after giving birth) will be recruited. There are five times of appointment or home visits by the trained personnel for each participant to complete this study, including 1) recruitment (28 weeks or more), 2) before delivery (below 36 weeks), 3) after delivery (1 week postpartum), 4) infant age at 6 weeks and 5) infant age at 6 months.

For each visit, we will provide a gift or voucher valued Rp 50,000 or equal to A$5 (a total of A$25).

q13.value: Because of this research is a pilot study investigating the association between the gut microbiome and infant growth, we planned to reach a total of 200 participants at the beginning of the study and estimated that 10% of them would drop out.

q14.value: We use the G*Power program to performs sample size analysis using the prevalence of stunting to calculate. After calculation, the minimum sample size is 686 (n1=n2=343) samples. However, considering the limited time of the research by only 14 months, and also the focus of the study is microbiome analysis, therefore, we decided to use only 200 participants for this analysis.

q15.value: The study will be conducted for up to 14 months. Therefore, this study will stop to recruit and follow up the participants by the date of 1st April 2021.

question.value: None

The outcomes that will be measured are:
1. The gut microbiota composition
2. Pregnancy outcomes, including birth weight, length and head circumference
3. Infant growth, indicating by length and weight.

From the length and weight, we will categorize the growth into two categories, namely stunting (height for age z score below -2 standard deviation/ SD) and normal (otherwise).

In addition, from the weight, we will categorize into three nutritional status indices, underweight (if the weight for age z score below -2 SD),  normal (-2 SD to 2 SD) and overweight (above 2 SD).

We will use ANOVA to compare the gut microbiota composition of the mother and infant, growth, and pregnancy outcomes.

Heatmaps analysis will be performed to describe the abundance of the gut microbiota composition using R software.

q20.value: One of the important cofounding variables, mental health, can only be analyzed after transforming from 20 questions. From the result of these questions, we will categorize into two categories, "normal" and with "mental health problem".

q21.value: We use p-value below 0.05 to determine the statistical difference among groups.

q23.value: We will exclude data which do not have the primary outcome, the gut microbiome.

q24.value: We will investigate the association between maternal gut microbiome and pregnancy outcomes mediated by maternal stress and nutrition intake. Meanwhile, the association between infant gut microbiome and growth will also be analyzed by including the covariates mode of delivery, infant feeding, maternal supplementation types, maternal stress, and the maternal gut microbiome.

q25.value:
Prior to gut microbiome analysis, we will conduct the DNA extraction process from fecal samples using QIAamp PowerFecal DNA kit. The extracted DNA is then analyzed using 16S qPCR.

We also will justify the result of the study by including the compliance of the participants regarding the supplement consumptions.

q1.value: The influence of gender and childhood economic status on implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts

q3.value: Gender differences between men and women lead to different attitudes toward math and music， the reason may be that men and women interpret math and music differently. childhood economic status may also influence attitudes toward math and music，the possible reasons are different economic status in childhood brings different time of first contact and different discipline construction.

q4.value: Negative bias towards math is stronger amongst female participants than males. Negative bias towards math is stronger amongst participants with good economic status in childhood than participants with bad economic status in childhood.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A 2×2 between-subject design, one factor is gender (male and female), the other is economic status in childhood (good and bad).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited at college and will be paid 10RMB for agreeing to participate.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 158 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 180, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Chose test family as F tests, test of power analysis as a priori, statistical test as ANOVA: Fixed effects, special, main effects and interactions. Fill in α err prob as 0.05, power as 0.8. First, we calculate the sample size for main effect of gender, fill in numerator df as 1, number of groups as 2. Determine effect size f as 0.32 because d is 0.64. The result of total sample size is 79. Second, we calculate the sample size for main effect of economic status in childhood, fill in numerator df as 1, number of groups as 2. Determine effect size f as 0.25. The result of total sample size is 128. Third, we calculate the sample size for interaction, fill in numerator df as 2, number of groups as 4. Determine effect size f as 0.25. The result of total sample size is 158. We pick the maximum , so the sample size of the study is 158.

q15.value: We will register the information of each subject to ensure the sample size is accurate.

question.value: We manipulated the economic status in childhood by 7 items in previous studies, such as "When I was a child, my family always worried about money", "When we were young, our family usually had enough money to buy what we wanted". The final score below 3 points is bad economic status in childhood，the rest is good economic status in childhood

The single outcome variable will be the implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts which uses the IAT task.(＜0 indicates more bias against math;0 indicates equal feelings between art/math; ＞0 indicates more bias against art).
We will use a  2 X 2 factorial measures ANOVA with both factors within subjects to analyze our results.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the treatments, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Visuo-spatial Memory for Data Comparison in Small Multiples Visualisation

q1.value: Visuo-spatial memory for data comparison in small multiples visualisation

q2.value: Jiazhou Liu, Tim Dwyer, Arnaud Prouzeau, Barrett Ens

q3.value:
A small multiple is a visualisation technique using a group of similar charts or models with the same axes or model reference to enhance the comparison of different data in the same dataset. The small multiple technique is currently widely used in the 2D context. However, there is little research on this technique for 3D data visualisation and comparison.

In this research, we aimed to investigate how people's spatial memory is affected by different spatial arrangements in immersive environments, will lead to general design guidelines for small-multiple visualisation in using current and future virtual and augmented reality devices.

q4.value:
H1: Participants will be more accurate in recalling highlighted panels in the flat condition than in the circular condition.
H2: Participants will answer more quickly in the flat condition than in the circular condition.
H3: Participant will find flat condition is less mentally demanding.
H4: Participant will find circular condition is less physically demanding.

name.value: First- vs. Third-person Perceptions of Secret Sharers (S1 February 2020)

sample.value: A power analysis using G*Power indicated that for power of .80 to detect an effect of .15 we would need 351 participants. We will aim to recruit 400 participants in order to have usable data from 351 people.

analyses.value: The analyses will consist of a 2 (perspective: first-person, third-person) X 2 (secret: shared, not shared) factorial ANOVA for each of the dependent variables (trustworthiness and value) and follow-up comparisons.

outliers.value: Manipulation checks will be included to ensure that participants paid adequate attention to the vignettes; those who fail manipulation check items--or bot check items--will be excluded from analyses.

dependent.value:
The primary dependent variables will be perceived trustworthiness value of a person who either shares or keeps someone else's secret.

 Trustworthiness will be assessed with five items taken from the trustworthiness sub-scale of the Witness Credibility Scale (Brodsky et al., 2010) in which participants rate each characteristic of Abby using eight-point bipolar scales. 

Value of Abby will be assessed by the welfare trade-off task (Sell et al., 2009), in which participants make a series of choices between two options. For each choice, one option entails themselves getting $0 while the other person (Abby) gets a sum of money, while the other option entails the other person (Abby) getting $0 while they get a sum of money.

conditions.value: Participants will read one of two vignettes in which a woman who knows a secret about one of her friends either shares or keeps that secret when talking with a mutual friend. Participants will be randomly assigned to read a vignette from a first-person perspective (they are asked to imagine they are close friends with both of the women in the vignette) or from a third-person perspective (they are asked to imagine three women who are mutual friends). Participants will thus be randomly assigned to one of four conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Why might we trust someone who shares a secret with us, even though breaking a confidence typically renders one less trustworthy? This study seeks to examine whether individuals trust friends more and feel closer to them when they share a third party's secret with them, relative to when individuals observe someone sharing a third party's secret with someone else. Sharing secrets with someone may be an indication of close friendship or intimacy, yet sharing others' secrets may indicate that someone is untrustworthy. This type of information may be perceived differently when an individual is directly involved in the transaction than when they witness the same transaction between others. 

We hypothesize that individuals will be perceived as more trustworthy and valuable as friends when they are observed sharing others' secrets from a first-person perspective relative to when they are observed sharing others' secrets from a third-person perspective.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
Why might we trust someone who shares a secret with us, even though breaking a confidence typically renders one less trustworthy? This study seeks to examine whether individuals trust friends more and feel closer to them when they share a third party's secret with them, relative to when individuals observe someone sharing a third party's secret with someone else. Sharing secrets with someone may be an indication of close friendship or intimacy, yet sharing others' secrets may indicate that someone is untrustworthy. This type of information may be perceived differently when an individual is directly involved in the transaction than when they witness the same transaction between others. 

We hypothesize that individuals will be perceived as more trustworthy and valuable as friends when they are observed sharing others' secrets from a first-person perspective relative to when they are observed sharing others' secrets from a third-person perspective.

q1.value: Stereotype-based employment discrimination of people with mental vs. physical disorders - Study 3

q2.value: Deborah Borowski, Ramona Allstadt Torras, Angela Rachael Dorrough, Andreas Glöckner

q3.value:
The results of two previous studies show that people with mental disorders, as compared to people with physical disorders, are discriminated against in a hypothetical reintegration hiring scenario (Study 1 and replicated in Study 2) and that this hiring-bias might not be eliminated by a social norm or by monetary incentives not to discriminate (Study 2). Nevertheless, a monetary incentive not to discriminate tends to result in a greater reduction of the hiring bias than both, a social norm and a combination of the monetary incentive and the social norm. Given that social norms (Bresnahan & Zhuang, 2016; Goldstein, Cialdini, & Griskevicius, 2008) as well as monetary incentives (Mantzari et al., 2015; Shaw & Gupta, 2015) have been shown capable of influencing people’s behavior, these results seem to be counterintuitive. Therefore, one of the aims of the present study is to replicate findings of the above mentioned studies with improved material. More specifically, materials of the previous studies will be adapted in the following ways:

-	The norm used in Study 2 (“It is expected from the committee that all applicants are considered in the application procedure, irrespective of the reason for their previous absence from work.”) rather resembles a disjunctive norm, because it suggests “what others think should be done” (Chung & Rimal, 2016, p. 6). As previous studies indicated that descriptive norms might be more powerful to change people’s behavior (Melnyk, van Herpen, Jak, & van Trijp, 2019), the present study will use such instead. That is, the norm will be rephrased in such a way that it rather emphasizes “what others actually do” (Chung & Rimal, 2016, p. 6; “All members of the committee, to which you belong, ensure that all applicants are considered in the application procedure, irrespective of the reason for their previous absence from work.”).
-	To ensure that sufficient attention is paid to both, general instructions as well as the manipulation, the latter will be presented after the general instructions. Thus, due to this separation, the manipulation will be more salient.
-	Control questions yielding at the deepened processing and understanding of the general instructions and those provided in the manipulation will be administered. More specifically, in order to make sure that participants have fully understood the general instructions, a test trial will be implemented. To exclude the possibility of influences on subsequent measures, the test trial was based on Pattern 1 adopted from Dorrough, Glöckner, Betsch, and Wille (2017), which has not been utilized for subsequent measurements. Moreover, information with regard to gender and disorder of the applicants will be removed from the test trial. In addition, manipulation specific control questions will be utilized and presented on the same page as the test trial: If the condition entails the presentation of the social norm (i.e., Condition 2 and 4), a control question with regard to this norm will be integrated. If the condition contains a monetary incentive (i.e., Condition 3 and 4), a control question with regard to the incentive will be included. Thus, besides the test trial, participants will be asked to answer no additional question in Condition 1, one additional question in Condition 2 (i.e., with regard to the norm), one additional question in Condition 3 (i.e., with regard to the incentive), and two additional questions in Condition 4 (i.e., with regard to both, norm and incentive). Moreover, for each of these questions, only one of the possible answers will be correct. Participants will subsequently receive feedback and will be presented with the repetition of instructions, if necessary. To prevent selective dropout due to varying numbers of control questions and the possibility of differences in difficulty, participants will be allowed to answer them multiple times and can only proceed after answering all of the control questions correctly.
-	As a manipulation check, after assessment of the main dependent variables, participants will be asked to provide an estimate of the percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria since it is reasoned that participants who were presented with the descriptive norm (i.e., Conditions 2 and 4) should assume this percentage to be higher than participants who did not receive such information.
-	To reduce the possibility of fatigue effects, the variable “mental and physical demands due to a certain occupation”, which previously had been assessed for other purposes, will be excluded.


In addition, based on the Stereotype Content Model (SCM, Fiske, 2012), which assumes that social judgments are formed by stereotypical perceptions along the two dimensions of warmth and competence, Study 1 and Study 2 indicated that the hiring bias is also mediated by perceived competence associated with the disorder. Given that the SCM states that the most negative judgments arise if the target is perceived to be low on both dimensions (i.e., competence and warmth) and in light of evidence suggesting that disorders do not only differ with regard to their perceived competence, but also with regard to their perceived warmth (Sadler, Meagor, & Kaye, 2012; Fiske, 2012), the second aim of the present study is to examine whether mental as compared to physical disorders do differ with respect to their perceived warmth and whether this influences the hiring bias, too.

q4.value:
As the current study is intended to gather data for several purposes, all hypotheses are listed below. The hypotheses that will be tested within a master’s thesis are written in bold letters.

In addition, contrary to the previous studies, the replication hypotheses will be tested across all four conditions rather than only for Condition 1, because the relationships are expected to be found in all four conditions. This, in turn, might also result in greater power to detect the below described relationships.

Replication hypotheses concerning all four conditions:
-	H1: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is predicted in a rational manner by job relevant cues (positive relation).
-	H2: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is higher for applicants with physical as compared to mental disorders (main effect of disorder (i.e., hiring bias)).
-	If H1 and H2 are confirmed, the cue validity of the cue mental vs. physical disorder and how much better an applicant with a mental disorder has to be according to job relevant cues (delta Bayes posterior probability) to be preferred over a person with a physical disorder will be calculated.

-	H3: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is influenced negatively by the expected long-term impairment (difference between the more and the less suitable applicant). It is hypothesized that the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder is (fully or partially) mediated by differences in expected long term impairment.
-	H4: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less competent (main effect of disorder).
-	H5: Across all conditions, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation is perceived to be lower for people with mental as compared to physical disorders (main effect of disorder).
-	H6: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived competence.

New hypotheses:
-	H7.0: It is hypothesized that in Conditions 2 (norm only), 3 (incentive only), and 4 (norm + incentive), the probability to choose the more suitable applicant will be higher in comparison to Condition 1.
      o	H7.1: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant increases with the presence of a social norm (main effect of norm).
      o	H7.2: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant with the presence of monetary incentives (main effect of incentive).
-	H8: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less warm (main effect of disorder).
-	H9: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived warmth.

Explorative analyses:
It will be exploratively investigated whether the expected effect of condition on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is moderated by perceived warmth of the disorder (i.e., interaction between condition and perceived warmth).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The study design will be a mixed factorial design (for details, see also variables section).

q9.value:
Following variables will be randomized:
•	instruction (i.e., conditions)
•	occupation
•	presentation order of the 10 mental disorders
•	physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (see also variables section)
•	gender of the applicants (see also variables section)
•	order of the patterns and the corresponding localization of the mental disorder (i.e., instead of reversing the patterns, the mental disorders will be located on either side)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participant recruitment and payment:
•	Participants will be recruited from the Decision Lab Cologne pool.
•	Participation will take about 60 minutes. As bank details have been registered within the basic survey of the Decision Lab Cologne, participants will be paid by bank transfers. The exact payment will depend on the condition, to which the participant has been assigned to:
      o	No norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	Norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	No norm/incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€ as it is expected that participants will solve about 2/3 of the tasks.
      o	Norm/Incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€.
Eligibility criteria:
•	Participants will be included, if they:
      o	are aged 18 or above
      o	agreed to the informed consent form
      o	indicated that they have heard of more than 4 of the presented disorders

Study timeline:
•	Decision Lab Cologne-ID
•	Informed consent and data protection notes
•	Random assignment to one of the four conditions (i.e., no norm / no incentive, norm / no incentive, no norm / incentive, norm / incentive)
      o	Presentation of general instructions with regard to the hiring scenario and the performance patterns
      o	Condition-specific instructions (i.e., manipulation)
      o	Test trial and, if applicable, control question(s) with subsequent feedback
      o	Choice of the applicant (i.e., 240 decisions in total)
      o	For each of the two applicants: assessment of the estimated likelihood he or she will be successful
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each (physical and mental) disorder (i.e., for 20 disorders in total)
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each occupation (i.e., three occupations in total)
•	Assessment of expected long-term impairment due to each disorder (0-100%)
•	Assessment of estimated percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria (i.e., manipulation check)
•	Assessment of whether one or more of the disorders are unknown to the participant
•	Assessment of demographic data (i.e., age, gender, participant occupation / student status)

q13.value: The required sample size has been determined a priori by means of G*Power version 3.1.9.2: Based on the central result, the main effect of disorder (mental vs. physical), the effect found in Study 2 (b = -0.749, OR = 0.4728392, p<.001) has been used. More specifically, “F-tests – ANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors” has been chosen as it is the closest approximation to the repeated-measurement regression. The effect size f=0.2065 with two measurements and four groups has been used, since the effect will be tested within each condition. For a power of 1- β = .95 and an alpha probability of 0.05, a sample size of n = 20 participants is required per group, resulting in a total sample size of N = 80 participants.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when the desired sample size has been reached.

question.value:
With a within-subject design, following variables will be manipulated:
-	10 mental disorders: alcohol dependence disorder, schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorder I, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic-stress-disorder, somatoform pain disorder, anorexia nervosa
-	Job relevant cues: final grades, work experience, working sample, job interview (+/-) varied across four possible patterns adopted from Dorrough et al. (2017; Pattern 3-6). The cue validities will be constant for all trials (for details, please see attached file).
-	Each combination of a certain mental vs. physical disorder will be shown with the opposite pattern of performances (+/-) by changing sides of the presented disorders, because mental and physical disorders will not be fully crossed (for an example, please see attached file).
-	Three occupations: architect, police officer, and department manager
-	Within-subjects variables, which are not fully crossed but counterbalanced across participants:
      o	10 physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (i.e., as the specific physical disorders are not part of the confirmatory analyses, disorders will not be fully crossed with all other factors)
      o	Applicants’ gender will be randomly assigned per trial (i.e., male and male or female and female)
Between-subjects variable:
-	Payment conditions (i.e., interventions): no norm/no incentive; norm/no incentive; no norm/incentive; norm/incentive

•	Manipulation check:
      o	Whether instructions provided in the manipulation have been understood
      o	Estimated percentage of decisions solely based on job-related criteria
•	Dependent variables:
      o	Choice for the more suitable applicant (participants will make 10 (mental disorder) x 4 (patterns) x 3 (occupations) x 2 (opposite patterns) =240 decisions)
      o	Estimated likelihood that applicants V and W will be successful in the occupation (11-point Likert scale from 0 (impossible) to 5 (50:50 Chance) to 10 (certain))
      o	Perceived warmth and competence of…
                - …each mental and physical disorder
                - …each occupation
•	Covariate:
      o	Expected long-term impairment due to disorders (0-100%)
•	Demographic variables:
      o	Participant age 
      o	Participant gender
      o	Participant occupation/student status
Warmth and competence scores will be calculated by averaging across the respective three items (see material).

Manipulation check:
In order to test whether the manipulation of the norm has been successful, an independent-samples t-test will be conducted. More specifically, the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria measured in Conditions 1 and 3 (i.e., conditions not including presentation of norm) will be tested against those measured in Conditions 2 and 4 (i.e., conditions including presentation of norm). The manipulation of the norm will be regarded as successful, if the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria is significantly greater in Conditions 2 and 4 than in Conditions 1 and 3.


Main analyses:
-	H1: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is predicted in a rational manner by job relevant cues (positive relation).
-	H2: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is higher for applicants with physical as compared to mental disorders (main effect of disorder (i.e., hiring bias)).
-	H3: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is influenced negatively by the expected long-term impairment (difference between the more and the less suitable applicant). It is hypothesized that the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder is (fully or partially) mediated by differences in expected long term impairment.

To test H1, H2, and H3, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder) and the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information) by means of a logistic regression analysis. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added (i.e., model 1). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method (i.e., will be entered simultaneously).


-	H4: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less competent (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H4, competence will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 2). Thus, H4 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H5: Across all conditions, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation is perceived to be lower for people with mental as compared to physical disorders (main effect of disorder).

To test H5, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation will be predicted by the same independent variable and covariates as described for model 2. For this multiple linear regression analysis, cluster correction and forced entry method will also be applied.


-	H6: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived competence.

To test H6, model 1 will be rerun, adding perceived competence of a certain disorder (difference of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Furthermore, a mediation analysis using bootstrapping to estimate standard errors (Preacher & Hayes, 2008) will be conducted.


-	H7.0: It is hypothesized that in Conditions 2 (norm only), 3 (incentive only), and 4 (norm + incentive), the probability to choose the more suitable applicant will be higher in comparison to Condition 1.
      o	H7.1: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant increases with the presence of a social norm (main effect of norm).
      o	H7.2: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant with the presence of monetary incentives (main effect of incentive).

The hypotheses H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2 will be analyzed by means of a logistic regression analysis. More specifically, the choice for the more suitable applicant (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant (i.e., the job relevant information), norm (0 = no; 1 = yes), and incentive (0 = no; 1 = yes). As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 3). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.


-	H8: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less warm (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H8, warmth will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 4). Thus, H8 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H9: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived warmth.

For H9, model 1 will be rerun, with perceived warmth of a certain disorder (difference of the perceived warmth of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Again, a mediation analysis as described above will be conducted.

q21.value:
For all statistical analyses, a statistical significance level of α = .05 will be applied. For directed hypotheses (i.e., H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H8), one-tailed tests will be applied, whereas interaction effects (i.e., H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2) will be analyzed by means of two-sided tests.
For indirect effects in mediation analyses (i.e., H3, H6, and H9), 95% CIs will be used.

q22.value: Missing data will result in exclusion of participants. Given that only mandatory questions will be used, this should just be relevant for dropouts.

q24.value:
In order to exploratively investigate whether the perceived warmth of the disorder moderates the expected effect of type of intervention on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by perceived warmth of a certain disorder, type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information), and condition (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 5). 
The reference category for the dummy-coded condition variable will be Condition 1, meaning that the interaction effects between perceived warmth and Condition 2, Condition 3, and Condition 4, respectively (i.e., three interaction effects) will be examined my closely. Thus, a logistic regression analysis with cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.

Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q9:
Following variables will be randomized:
•	instruction (i.e., conditions)
•	occupation
•	presentation order of the 10 mental disorders
•	physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (see also variables section)
•	gender of the applicants (see also variables section)
•	order of the patterns and the corresponding localization of the mental disorder (i.e., instead of reversing the patterns, the mental disorders will be located on either side)
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: The required sample size has been determined a priori by means of G*Power version 3.1.9.2: Based on the central result, the main effect of disorder (mental vs. physical), the effect found in Study 2 (b = -0.749, OR = 0.4728392, p<.001) has been used. More specifically, “F-tests – ANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors” has been chosen as it is the closest approximation to the repeated-measurement regression. The effect size f=0.2065 with two measurements and four groups has been used, since the effect will be tested within each condition. For a power of 1- β = .95 and an alpha probability of 0.05, a sample size of n = 20 participants is required per group, resulting in a total sample size of N = 80 participants.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be terminated when the desired sample size has been reached.
registration_responses.q21:
For all statistical analyses, a statistical significance level of α = .05 will be applied. For directed hypotheses (i.e., H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H8), one-tailed tests will be applied, whereas interaction effects (i.e., H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2) will be analyzed by means of two-sided tests.
For indirect effects in mediation analyses (i.e., H3, H6, and H9), 95% CIs will be used.
registration_responses.q22: Missing data will result in exclusion of participants. Given that only mandatory questions will be used, this should just be relevant for dropouts.
registration_responses.q24:
In order to exploratively investigate whether the perceived warmth of the disorder moderates the expected effect of type of intervention on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by perceived warmth of a certain disorder, type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information), and condition (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 5). 
The reference category for the dummy-coded condition variable will be Condition 1, meaning that the interaction effects between perceived warmth and Condition 2, Condition 3, and Condition 4, respectively (i.e., three interaction effects) will be examined my closely. Thus, a logistic regression analysis with cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Participant recruitment and payment:
•	Participants will be recruited from the Decision Lab Cologne pool.
•	Participation will take about 60 minutes. As bank details have been registered within the basic survey of the Decision Lab Cologne, participants will be paid by bank transfers. The exact payment will depend on the condition, to which the participant has been assigned to:
      o	No norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	Norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	No norm/incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€ as it is expected that participants will solve about 2/3 of the tasks.
      o	Norm/Incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€.
Eligibility criteria:
•	Participants will be included, if they:
      o	are aged 18 or above
      o	agreed to the informed consent form
      o	indicated that they have heard of more than 4 of the presented disorders

Study timeline:
•	Decision Lab Cologne-ID
•	Informed consent and data protection notes
•	Random assignment to one of the four conditions (i.e., no norm / no incentive, norm / no incentive, no norm / incentive, norm / incentive)
      o	Presentation of general instructions with regard to the hiring scenario and the performance patterns
      o	Condition-specific instructions (i.e., manipulation)
      o	Test trial and, if applicable, control question(s) with subsequent feedback
      o	Choice of the applicant (i.e., 240 decisions in total)
      o	For each of the two applicants: assessment of the estimated likelihood he or she will be successful
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each (physical and mental) disorder (i.e., for 20 disorders in total)
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each occupation (i.e., three occupations in total)
•	Assessment of expected long-term impairment due to each disorder (0-100%)
•	Assessment of estimated percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria (i.e., manipulation check)
•	Assessment of whether one or more of the disorders are unknown to the participant
•	Assessment of demographic data (i.e., age, gender, participant occupation / student status)
registration_responses.q16.question:
With a within-subject design, following variables will be manipulated:
-	10 mental disorders: alcohol dependence disorder, schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorder I, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic-stress-disorder, somatoform pain disorder, anorexia nervosa
-	Job relevant cues: final grades, work experience, working sample, job interview (+/-) varied across four possible patterns adopted from Dorrough et al. (2017; Pattern 3-6). The cue validities will be constant for all trials (for details, please see attached file).
-	Each combination of a certain mental vs. physical disorder will be shown with the opposite pattern of performances (+/-) by changing sides of the presented disorders, because mental and physical disorders will not be fully crossed (for an example, please see attached file).
-	Three occupations: architect, police officer, and department manager
-	Within-subjects variables, which are not fully crossed but counterbalanced across participants:
      o	10 physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (i.e., as the specific physical disorders are not part of the confirmatory analyses, disorders will not be fully crossed with all other factors)
      o	Applicants’ gender will be randomly assigned per trial (i.e., male and male or female and female)
Between-subjects variable:
-	Payment conditions (i.e., interventions): no norm/no incentive; norm/no incentive; no norm/incentive; norm/incentive
